comments.body: typo: tran**s**formation
Done.
This should have more detail since the definition of FractionalOffset probably can't help.
(same comment for other classes with this field)
We should probably use `..` cascade here.  I realize you're following the existing pattern, but this just occurred to me.
Filed https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/1381. Not sure it's worth it, though. I would hope the resulting code would be identical, and with the current pattern the code is more consistent.
Do you want to reference CustomOneChildLayout too?
man, this is really not much of a class, huh.
this might collide
I suspect we'll end up wanting to namspace our globals at some point. :)
namespacing is under the control of the importer (import ... as).
(e.g. we regularly namespaces dart:ui imports "as ui", and mojom imports "as mojom".)
not sure "using a variety of different styles" quite conveys the right impression here.
i don't know what you mean by "displayed on the layout constraints"
Oh man, somehow I left out like six words from that sentence.
I think it'd be clearer if you said "...an associated style that is used...".
mention [DefaultTextStyle.of] so they don't go and try to walk the tree to find the nearest one or something
When...
"on the layout constraints" again
strike "by default" since you started with "when omitted".
`* [Center] (which is the same as Align but with the [alignment] always set to 0.5,0.5)` or some such
under Center, say something about Align.
explain when you'd prefer stack or flow over multichildcustomlayout
as opposed to what?
as with other places, mention why you'd prefer the others
2.0 might be a better example since 0.5 will cause overflow
we should be consistent about whether we put the description in parentheses or not (here and anywhere else we do this)
if we don't have parentheses, we should put a comma after the class name
The `[Foo] (one line explanation)` pattern has already been established, I will follow.
What's "an overflow box"?

I lifted the name from the widget's renderer, RenderFractionallySizedOverflowBox. I thought we used the name to identify widgets that didn't pass the constraints they were given to their child. 

Even if all of that is true, it's not likely that our dear reader will know as much, so I took the whole qualifying expression out.
above you use "given", here you use "to give". we should be consistent.
asks
asks
painters paint
see earlier comment
delegates
custom
see earlier comments
widget?
We usually use either noun phrases or sentences. This is something else.
Yeah, this came from a misguided attempt to make the render object and widget text the same.
comma before "because"
Crazy.  http://www.quickanddirtytips.com/education/grammar/when-to-use-a-comma-before-because
we should be consistent about metadata vs meta data.
I went with "meta data" everywhere because that's what the code went with, but metadata seems to be accepted usage as well.
this could probably do with more motivation. It's not at all clear why you'd use this.
these docs should talk about the importance of [mainAxis].
should we have a `static final Container empty = new Container(width: 0.0, height: 0.0)` ?
Any `empty` widget would make more sense as a SizedBox...

I know I started this trend, but I think we should move from `* foo (which blah)` to `* foo, which blah` (or `*foo, blah` in some cases). The parentheses don't work in all the cases where I want to use this pattern. I can do that in a later pass though.
it doesn't return true from hitTest, its render object does
missing period
"since" -> "because" is to you what "++i" -> "i += 1" is to me, huh

http://blog.apastyle.org/apastyle/2011/05/since-versus-because.html

I forget which of the style guides drilled it into me.

The dictionary just gives both definitions as being fine. :-)

(I have no problem with us using `because` instead of `since`. I just think it's funny.)
s/Using/Use/ or s/to make/makes/.
`@required` ?
It's a render object widget, and the render object can handle not having a child.
but that may size => but might be sized
It's not clear why the FittedBox is needed here.

i've added a comment:
```
///         fit: BoxFit.contain, // otherwise the logo will be tiny
```
I wonder if terms like 'left-aligned' are going to haunt us when RTL layouts are supported.
that's why i refer specifically to the example (which is in English). I agree we shouldn't say left-aligned in general.
please add some more depth to this specific documentation, e.g. giving an example of where you'd use this
(but leave this one the same, so that the reader can see different ways to describe this same behaviour and hopefully understand one of them!)
this would be a great place to copy the informative paragraph you wrote for RenderCustomPaint (this is more likely to be seen than the other). Duplicating the docs is fine.
apply earlier fixes to these two docs too

I'd like to see unit tests for the widgets to which you added the ability to use FractionalOffsetGeometry, including some cases of weird combinations, to prove out whether the FractionalOffsetGeometry logic makes as much sense as the EdgeInsetsGeometry logic.
(e.g. testing edge cases of changing from topLeft to topStart and seeing if it works right, or testing lerping, or whatnot)
Added.
this should probably elaborate on what "a button" means.

I'm not sure how to elaborate what a button means, I could try to describe it as something tap-able,  but not everything that's tap-able should have this flag set to true.

Instead I added some documentation of how this affects TalkBack/VoiceOver (provides a "button" hint)
copy all the documentation you add for the callbacks above into these too, they're even more the front-line docs.
Done.
we should probably allow the locale to be explicitly overridden here
(like the textDirection)
Why less subtly?
Added: "because it is either visible or hidden, rather than allowing fractional opacity values"

\o/

I get asked all the time how to make a NullWidget in case you have to pass something. Perhaps we should even re-wrap this in a more-discoverably-named syntactic-sugar widget?
@xster We've been using `Empty` and `Blank` as widgets in our app's which are just inherited from `SizedBox` with no width and height. Those could be quite good names as a synonym for a "NullWidget".
It's generally even better to just not include any widget at all.
I agree. I think @xster was talking about when you have to pass a child widget. Quite a lot of the time child is not optional and passing null will not work. This is the case for this "NullWiget"
But when you have to pass a widget, it just means you can go up higher and not pass the very widget that you are in. :-)
Hard to know how my choice process should be differently colored by the '(albeit less subtly)'
clarified
@gspencergoog do you know why this sample code section doesn't work?.
"Doesn't work" in what sense?
https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/21764/checks?check_run_id=21624772 The sample code check thinks it is a class/method declaration
It looks "normal" to me.  You might check at the top of the file for a `// Examples can assume:` block that breaks this code, maybe.
The issue was the level of indentation apparently
Maybe add: Semantic indexes are used by TalkBack/Voiceover to make announcements about the current scroll state, e.g. "<example announcement>".
nit: blank line before \`\`\`dart
Done.
btw, sample code should always be in a sample section so that the analyzer catches it. looks like this sample code ended up not in a sample code section.
@Hixie : what's my option here? Since it's already in `## Transparent image` section, can I create a sub-section `### Sample code`?
nit: first paragraph should just be one sentence.
Fixed.

(from offline discussion)

It seems like this class is not wired up to receive Hover events from the gesture binding (it only receives events that have a hit test result, which exclude hover events).

We should probably move what's implemented in MouseDetector into the Listener and remove MouseDetector altogether. That way, there's one Widget (Listener) that deals with all kinds of Pointer events, including hover. (And we should also add some tests to ensure that Listener.onPointerHover actually fires as expected.)
Excellent idea! Done.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +5082,5086 @@    this.onPointerEnter,
    this.onPointerExit,
    this.onPointerHover,
    this.onPointerUp,
    this.onPointerCancel,

comments.body: I think in this case it would be better to just do `## Sample code`
No, it should be using what was there.  Every other sample in the app is using the "blue box" sample rendering, which includes a copy button, etc.
Sorry for the confusion - I misread the docs
We can remove this since this will be in a `## Sample code` heading.
you might say the "100x100 [Align] widget".
You might say "40x40 red [Container]".
this is begging for screenshots.

I will add code that generates them to https://github.com/flutter/assets-for-api-docs. For further discussion here's what the two samples produce when running on a phone:

![img_0010](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1227763/52886900-ba919000-312a-11e9-91c8-e461d7d845dd.PNG)

![img_0011](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1227763/52886908-be251700-312a-11e9-8216-d856f26128be.PNG)
Actually, our diagram generating infrastructure currently can't handle blurs: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/28028
Maybe "to the content that was already painted within its bounds"?
It seems to happily apply the filter outside its bounds if a child decided to paint outside the bounds...
Can we wrap/change the behavior of the BackdropFilter so users don't need to learn about this distinction? (or do they?)
I would love to make this more intuitive. Do you have an idea how that can be achieved, though?
Maybe there's a much smarter fix that can be done at the layer level, @liyuqian might know. Otherwise, out of convenience, we can just emulate the below behavior in the framework?
https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/28174

After talking to @liyuqian we will do this in two steps: I am going to submit this PR with the updated documentation of how the BackdropFilter currently works. When @liyuqian finds some time, he will finish #28174 to change the behavior of this to something more reasonable.
